thread.section_title: Small Business | Finance & Small Businesses | News.com.au
thread.title: Sydney’s most epic renovation

author: Aidan Devine
title: Sydney’s most epic renovation
text:
THE OWNER of a 120-year-old Leichhardt home is expected to sell her property for $2 million more than she purchased it for after undertaking a mammoth renovation.
TV personality Cherie Barber purchased the 400sq m property in 2008 for $950,000 and spent years transforming the workman’s cottage into a luxury home expected to sell for over $3 million when it goes to auction September 5.
BEFORE: 93 Hill St’s front facade in 2008. Source: Supplied
AFTER: 93 Hill St’s front entrance today. Source: Supplied
Ms Barber said that when she first purchased the property at 93 Hill Street it was in an unliveable state. It still had an original two storey barn at the rear and was crumbling from the inside and out. The back of the home before the renovation. Source: Supplied
RECOGNISE ANYTHING? The back of the home after renovation. Source: Supplied
“I purchased the property in 2008 and saw potential,” Ms Barber said, adding that she set herself a challenge to gut and transform the home into a “gorgeous” property. She fused Victorian and industrial styles to achieve the look of the home, taking inspiration from the rear barn.
The kitchen had fallen into disrepair. Source: Supplied
Now the kitchen includes marble finishes. Source: Supplied
Ms Barber purchased the home for $950,000. Source: Supplied
Comparable properties have recently sold for above $3 million. Source: Supplied
The house boasts five bedrooms, luxurious bathrooms, a master wing with a study and 14 person spa. The kitchen is decked in marble, while other additions include a home theatre and self-contained studio retreat equipped with its own kitchen and bathroom.
The property took years to renovate. Source: Supplied
The new interior blends industrial and Victorian style. Source: Supplied
Selling agent Ben Southwell from Cobden & Hayson-Annandale said few properties match the home’s scale and size. The property includes five bedrooms and a self-contained “retreat”. Source: Supplied
93 Hill St will got to auction September 5. Source: Supplied
The renovation work was extensive. Source: Supplied
“This home represents great buying as you couldn’t replace the home for what you can buy it for,” Mr Southwell said. More than 75 groups have already passed through the home and six contracts have been issued.
The growth in value between the purchase price and estimated selling price has equated to roughly $300,000 in additional value for every year Ms Barber has owned the home.
Originally published as Epic reno adds $2m to house value
